creator: harm5304@gmail.com
text:
Environment:
Windows Server 2003 SP2
PHP 5.2.5
httpd 2.0.63
httpd 2.2.8
IIS 6.0
FireFox 2.0.0.11
Internet Explorer 6 and 7
Adobe Reader 8.1.1

I have a PHP webpage which launches a script that populates a PDF file stored 
on the server using FDF (not the toolkit).  The output of this script is then 
sent to the browser using a 'Content-type: application/vnd.fdf' header.
Here is the output from the PHP script:
%FDF-1.2

District)>><</T(CLIENT_NAME)/V(Maple Valley School District)>><</T(60)/V
(846000817)>><</T(FEDERAL_ID)/V(846000817)>><</T(61)/V(7009 S Potomac St)>><</T
(CLIENT_ADDRESS)/V(7009 S Potomac St)>><</T(62)/V(Centennial, CO, 80233)>><</T
(CLIENT_ADDRESS_INFO)/V(Centennial, CO, 80233)>>] 
/F (http://127.0.0.1:8082/downloads/w2.pdf) /ID [ 
<71cacfda3e29c932b81a10331ab33955>
] >> 
>> 
endobj
trailer
<<
/Root 1 0 R 

>>
%%EOF

Using Apache 2.0.63 and 2.2.8 this script launches in Adobe Reader in a 
FireFox browser but not in an Internet Explorer browser.  IE displays a page 
can not be found error.  I thought this might be a Microsoft bug, except this 
script works in both browsers in IIS 6.0.  So now I am thinking it is a bug 
with Apache.

Can someone please look into this?  I really don't want to tell users if you 
are using Apache you have to use FireFox.

Thanks,
Harmony

creator: slive@apache.org
text:
Since we really have no idea where the problem lies, this would be much better
dealt with on a user-support forum like the users@httpd.apache.org mailing list.

But before posting there, take a look at the exact HTTP response headers output
by Apache versus IIS so you can try to figure out why this is triggering
different behavior. This page might help you with that:
http://wiki.apache.org/httpd/WatchingHttpHeaders

Here are the response headers between IIS and IE:
HTTP Status Code: HTTP/1.1 302 Moved Temporarily  
Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0 
CRLF 
Pragma: no-cache CRLF 
Content-Length: 169 CRLF 
Content-Type: text/html CRLF 
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT CRLF 
Location: login.php?ReturnURL=map-pdf-fields.php?yr=2003 CRLF 
Server: Microsoft-IIS/6.0 CRLF 
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.2.5 CRLF 
Set-Cookie: PHPSESSID=5jr7gt12k6js4irpn5f12e4e17; path=/ CRLF 
X-Powered-By: ASP.NET CRLF 
Date: Wed, 30 Jan 2008 17:56:55 GMT CRLF 
Connection: close CRLF 

Here are the headers between Apache and IE:
HTTP Status Code: HTTP/1.1 302 Found  
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT CRLF 
Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0 
CRLF 
Pragma: no-cache CRLF 
Location: login.php?ReturnURL=map-pdf-fields.php?yr=2007 CRLF 
Content-Type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-1 CRLF 
Set-Cookie: PHPSESSID=jog2da0noohe8u9sru897l4j13; path=/ CRLF 
Connection: Close CRLF 
Server: Oracle-Application-Server-10g/10.1.2.0.2 Oracle-HTTP-Server OracleAS-
Web-Cache-10g/10.1.2.0.2 (N;ecid=3710851743744,0) CRLF 
Date: Wed, 30 Jan 2008 18:06:59 GMT CRLF 
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.2.5 CRLF 

Now what?
creator: harm5304@gmail.com

text:
1.  Both of those sets of headers are hopelessly broken, and badly violate HTTP.
2.  It's pretty clear it's the application, not either of the webservers, that's
responsible for the brokenness.
3.  They're nothing to do with the original problem description.
4.  The server you've described as Apache identifies itself as Oracle.  We're
not responsible for what Oracle do with it, but they should presumably be
providing support.
5.  If you have a problem with Apache, you've already been told what to do.
creator: nick@webthing.com
